headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Steve, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Q4 Full Year 2015 Nielsen Holdings plc Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] SVP of Investor Relations, Kate Va
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Steve, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Q4 Full Year 2015 Nielsen Holdings plc Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] SVP of Investor Relations, Kate Vanek, you may begin your conference.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks so much, Steve, and good morning, everybody. Thank you for joining us to discuss Nielsen's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Financial Performance. Joining me on the call from Nielsen is Mitch Barns, Chief Executive Officer; and Jamere Jackson, Chi
componenttext:
Thanks so much, Steve, and good morning, everybody. Thank you for joining us to discuss Nielsen's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Financial Performance. Joining me on the call from Nielsen is Mitch Barns, Chief Executive Officer; and Jamere Jackson, Chief Financial Officer. A slide presentation that we'll use on the call is available under the Events section of our IR website at nielsen.com/investors. 
Before we begin our prepared remarks, I'd like to remind all of you that the following discussion contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor provision of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements may include comments about Nielsen's outlook, expectations and prospects and are based on Nielsen's view as of today, February 11, 2016. 
We will be discussing non-GAAP measures during this morning's call for which we have provided reconciliations in the appendices of today's presentation and will be posted on our website. Our actual results in future periods may differ materially from those currently expected because of a number of risks and uncertainties. The risks and uncertainties that we believe are material are outlined in Nielsen's 10-K and other filings and materials, which you can also find on our website. [Operator Instructions]
And with that, I'd like to turn it over to our CEO, Mitch Barns.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kate. Good morning, everyone, thanks for joining us on the call. 2015 was a banner year for Nielsen. On a constant currency basis, we posted another year of mid-single digit revenue growth, margin expansion and record free cash flow, despite the v
componenttext:
Thanks, Kate. Good morning, everyone, thanks for joining us on the call. 2015 was a banner year for Nielsen. On a constant currency basis, we posted another year of mid-single digit revenue growth, margin expansion and record free cash flow, despite the volatile economic backdrop. Steady, consistent and resilient, that's who we are. 
In 2015, our top priority and biggest accomplishment was total Audience Measurement, our comprehensive system that provides comparable measurement across all screens and platforms. Today, total audience is here, between the market and is gaining traction with our clients, and I'm extremely proud of our team's execution. 
Looking at the business more broadly. Leveraging our measurement and analytics to help our clients make the important connections that drive their business is what we've done for nearly 93 years. And in a world of growing complexity and speed, our platform-based system oriented approach is nicely aligned with where our clients are going. It helped drive a number of wins across our Watch and Buy segments in 2015. Let's take a quick look at our financial performance for the full year.
First, we had strong revenue growth. On a constant currency basis, 2015 revenues grew 5%, 0.5 point better than our core revenue growth in 2014. Adjusted EBITDA was up 7.2% constant currency, reflecting the scalability of our business model and ongoing productivity improvements. Adjusted net income per share grew 12.4% constant currency to $2.53. Free cash flow was a record $804 million, up 18% over the prior year. Our strong free cash flow gives us the flexibility to invest in our growth initiatives, while also returning cash to our shareholders. Through our dividends and share repurchase, we returned over $1 billion to shareholders in 2015. 
In December, we announced an additional share buyback authorization of $500 million, bringing us to a total of approximately $850 million at year-end. Driving shareholder value through capital allocation remains a key priority for us. 
Acquisitions are also an integral part of our balanced capital allocation strategy and the stand out acquisition for us in 2015 was eXelate, which added to our ability to help buyers and the sellers of advertising act with more precision and speed. Importantly, we leveraged this acquisition, creating enterprise marketing platform or EMP. This system connects Nielsen data with a wide range of other data sources to help advertisers move from targeting segments of consumers to addressing individual consumers. It's a powerful capability. Lastly, we're reiterating our guidance for 2016. 
Next let's take a look at the fourth quarter highlights. First, Watch. Fourth quarter Watch revenues increased just over 5%. In addition to the growth from our traditional client base, we're also seeing faster growth with our Digital clients, including the big players like Google and Facebook. By the way, we announced last month that we'll be adding Facebook conversations to our existing Twitter feed to fuel our Nielsen Social Content Ratings for TV programs, previously known as Nielsen Twitter TV ratings. We also plan to Instagram data in the near future. 
Our Total Audience Measurement framework was a key driver of our performance in the quarter. On our last call, we talked about the 4 phases we see as the industry moves towards adoption of a new currency: Execute, evaluate, adopt and transact.
First, execute. We've done this. The system is built, and it's available in the market. We brought more than 2 dozen deliverables to the marketplace in 2015 alone. 
Next, evaluate and adopt, these are iterated steps and this is by design. Our clients need time to assess how the new metrics will impact their business and they need flexibility as they explore different ways to monetize their content and we built that flexibility right into the system. 
Let's look at some of the key components. First, Digital Ad Ratings. Digital Ad ratings is now in 17 countries, covering 85% of the global digital ad spend. Revenue doubled in 2015. In January, we successfully completed our beta period on Google's DoubleClick platform, so we're now fully live with DoubleClick in 8 countries. And ours is the only independent digital advertising metric available on the DoubleClick platform outside the U.S. We also continue to gain share with major advertisers, and the most recent is Mandalays [ph] who has chosen Nielsen as its digital advertising measurement provider. 
Moving on to VOD. In 2015, we launched several new measurement solutions, enabling us to cover a variety of video-on-demand viewing situations. If it's VOD or DVR viewing from your cable, satellite or telco provider, no matter whether it's seen within 3 days, 7 days or up to 35 days of the original area, we measure it. If it's VOD from one of the popular subscription-based or as-supported VOD providers, we measure that too. We're doing exactly that now for a wide range of networks and studios. We now cover over 6,000 different program episodes, most of which are viewed through Netflix. All together, our clients are using various metrics to drive about content licensing and advertising monetization decisions.
Next, Digital Content Ratings. Our progress with Digital continued in Q4 and into this year. Diverse group of networks, MVPDs and publishers are already fully operational with another dozen or so currently in process. Notably, a major digital video platform will begin receiving data from us next week. 
As we've said before, our approach to measuring each of the parts, in this case, VOD, digital video and linear TV, is to ensure the measurement of each is comparable, so they can put together to form total content ratings. The ability to provide this comprehensive view of the consumer is unique to Nielsen. It's what enables us to provide our clients with a de-duplicated view of their total audience, putting television and digital video on an even playing field, which is crucial to how clients think about their business going forward. We now have over 70 individual networks signed up for total content ratings and as more clients enable measurement of their digital and VOD content, that number will continue to grow. 
We've also invested in our measurement of linear television viewing. In 2015, we effectively doubled the size of our gold standard U.S. panel. The work is complete and ratings are live in the market. And the larger panel provides greater ratings stability important, especially for the smaller networks that also adds more analytical power to our Total Audience Measurement system. In fact, all of these initiatives contribute to the growing adoption of Nielsen's Total Audience Measurement system, which leads us to the fourth phase, transact.
As we mentioned at our December Analyst Day, we've had successful meetings with a full range of key industry leaders regarding the need to move the currency definition beyond the current C3 and C7. Additional meetings will occur over the next few weeks. Our clients are highly engaged and there's broad-based commitment to redefine the currency to one that's more reflective of how today's consumers watch content. We're confident that no matter how the currency is redefined, our Total Audience Measurement system will support it. In the meantime, we know it's already helped shape how our clients are approaching and thinking about the 2016 upfronts. 
Before I leave the Watch and turn to Buy, I want to touch on Marketing Effectiveness business. We had another strong quarter with revenue up more than 30% as we continue to help both buyers and sellers of media drive better marketing ROI. We strengthened our positioned in this area during the fourth quarter by increasing our stake into Nielsen Catalina Solutions, a business that's perfectly aligned with our strategy. 
Turning to Buy. As we close 2015, our Buy business continued to strengthen and expand. Revenues grew nearly 6% in the quarter, led by emerging markets as well as solid growth in key developed markets, including the U.S. and Europe. We continue to win new clients in the relatively faster-growing mid-tier and small client segments. Just last week, Dole Foods, named Nielsen as their preferred provider of consumer information and analytics. 
We also continue to strengthen our positions with retailers around the world. Retailers are long-term data partners for Nielsen, but they also have a growing need for our analytics to help with their advertising, marketing and merchandising decisions, both online and offline. Our business with retailers saw strong growth in 2015, boosted in part by 40 new e-commerce clients worldwide. 
Emerging markets grew 8.4% in Q4, despite more challenging economic conditions in many key markets. You've heard us say before that when our teams execute well, they're able to find growth even when GDP growth slows because we're still gaining penetration in many emerging markets and our results illustrate this. For example, in 3 key markets, Brazil, Russia and Turkey, our business grew double digits, well above the GDP growth in those markets. 
The secret here really isn't any secret. Comes down to good old-fashioned execute and by our teams, taking our proven product portfolio to new clients, while helping our existing clients manage through the changing market conditions. Our team did a great job. 
Developed markets also exited the year with good momentum. Revenues increased 4.8% in Q4. And notably, this was helped by Europe where we're starting to see growth at the region level, low single digits, but growth, and we're happy to have it. 
And parallel with total audience on the Watch inside, our Buy business is building its own version called total consumer measurements. The idea is to measure all consumer purchases as buying behavior continues to fragment across channels and segments. As millennials carve a path for a new way to buy, for instance, e-commerce, mobile devices and subscription models, we, too, are carving out new ways to measure the full range of consumer purchasing, following the proven formula that combines our high-quality panels with big data to provide the quality, granularity and efficiency that our clients require. 
Measurement is the core of our business and our objective is full coverage. Total audience and Watch, total consumer and Buy. We don't measure just one screen or one channel of distribution. Our objective is to measure all of them and we do that by focusing on and following the consumer. 
Before I close, let me revisit the 3 major trends and the related key investments that will drive our growth in 2016 and beyond. The first is the well-known trend that audiences are fragmenting across screens and platforms, and for us, that means our measurement needs to cover all viewing environments providing comparable metrics for each. 
Our Total Audience Measurement system does exactly that and its adoption continues to grow among our clients. 
The second is that consumers are reacting to ads and brands differently and they're buying in new ways and across new channels. Advertisers want to harness the power of big data to enable them to market to those change in consumers with greater precision and with proven ROI on their marketing spend. This is what our enterprise marketing platform enables. 
The third trend is that our clients information and analytics needs are growing and changing. Clients what data and systems to help them to act and they want more efficiency, speed and precision. This is the basis for our investment in eXelate in the enterprise marketing platform that I just talked about, but it's also the basis for our investment in our Buy platform, the connected Buy system that you heard us talk about at our Analyst Day in December. Clients want to know what consumers are buying, why they're buying it and what action they should take next. 
In all 3 key areas, our platform-oriented, system-based approach provides scalability, flexibility and speed, especially when our systems connect directly to our client systems. And because we own the essential core data, no one is better positioned to do it than Nielsen. 
To sum up, we feel great about our progress and confident about the year ahead. While we certainly don't wish for difficult economic conditions, we're ready for them. In fact, we know from experience that when economic conditions grow more challenging, our business model advantages and strengths show through more clearly. 
Over to you, Jamere.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mitch. It was a great year for Nielsen, and I'm especially proud of the contributions of my colleagues around the world. Our teams have had a laser focus on execution and efforts are reflected in our fourth quarter and 2015 results. Our results
componenttext:
Thank you, Mitch. It was a great year for Nielsen, and I'm especially proud of the contributions of my colleagues around the world. Our teams have had a laser focus on execution and efforts are reflected in our fourth quarter and 2015 results. Our results are also indicative of the consistency and resiliency of the Nielsen model and our ability to deliver solid results through the cycles. 
First, let me give a few more details on our 2015 performance. Revenue was just under $6.2 billion, up 5% constant currency, which is slightly above the high end of the revenue range we gave. We have delivered 38 consecutive quarters of constant currency revenue growth behind solid execution on our growth initiatives. 
Our Watch business grew 4.9% on a constant currency basis and we entered 2016 with great momentum behind our total audience Execution. 
Our Buy business grew 5% as an investments in the emerging markets and new client wins continue to deliver solid growth. 
Adjusted EBITDA was just under $1.9 billion, up 7.2% constant currency and adjusted EBITDA margins were 30.1%, up 61 basis points on a constant currency basis as we executed on our productivity initiatives and delivered margin expansion in both our Watch and Buy segments. 
Adjusted net income was $975 million, up 8.5% constant currency and diluted adjusted net income per share was $2.63, up 12.4% versus prior year on a constant currency basis. Our adjusted net income per share growth was driven by solid operating earnings and execution of our share buyback program. 
We generated record free cash flow, $804 million, up 18.1% versus the year-ago. Our free cash flow conversion of adjusted net income was 82%, up 12 points versus the year-ago, driven by EBITDA growth and working capital management. And as I look ahead, I continue to see opportunities for working capital efficiencies within our business that will continue to drive our free cash flow growth. 
And finally, we delivered a record $1.1 billion back to shareholders in the form of dividends and buybacks in 2015, demonstrating our continued commitment to drive incremental shareholder value through capital allocation. Again, a great year and solid execution of our teams around the world. 
Let me move to the fourth quarter. Revenue was $1.6 billion, up 5.6% constant currency. We had a strong finish to the year with solid revenue growth in both Watch and Buy. Adjusted EBITDA was $531 million, up 7.1% constant currency and adjusted EBITDA margins were 32.7%, up 45 basis points on a constant currency basis, as we delivered margin expansion in both our Watch and Buy segments for the sixth consecutive quarter. 
Adjusted net income was $300 million, up 3.1% constant currency and diluted adjusted net income per share was $0.82, up 7.9% versus the prior year on a constant currency basis. 
Finally, we generated $306 million in free cash flow, up an impressive 16.3% versus a year ago. However, our cash flow performance was significantly impacted in the quarter by the severe flooding in one of our major collection centers in Chennai, India, as well as currency impact from the stronger dollar. Despite this, we finished with our second-highest quarterly free cash flow performance ever. As Mitch said, we finished the year on a strong note and we have tremendous momentum heading into 2016.
Next, I'll move to the segments. First is our Watch segment. Our Watch segment had another great quarter, revenue was $745 million, up 5.2% constant currency. Our growth initiatives performed well as Audience Measurement ex-audio, which we know referred to as Audience Measurement of video and text was up 7.6%.
As we talked about last quarter, audio was down 6.9% as the timing of some deliveries were realized in the third quarter, which did not repeat in the fourth quarter. And for those of you who followed us since we acquired Arbitron, you will recall that our deliveries do not always sync up with the quarterly calendar causing our yield results to appear lumpy. But in 2015, the highly profitable Audio business delivered low single-digit revenue growth, outstanding margins and strong free cash flow. Marketing Effectiveness was up 31.3% behind strong quarters in the eXelate product offerings and the performance of the Nielsen Catalina Solutions, or NCS joint venture, which we increased our ownership stake in the fourth quarter, as I mentioned at the Analyst Day. I would also point out that you will see in our filings in GAAP net income loss that we realized $158 million nonoperating gain on the step-up in our base [indiscernible] as a result of our now majority stake in the joint venture. Our majority ownership stake contributed about 1 point to our Watch revenue growth in fourth quarter.
In 2015, Marketing Effectiveness was up 21% as we transformed the portfolio, while making investments in eXelate and NCS while we can go markets growing demand for solutions that help publishers and advertisers better identify, acquire and retain audiences across all screens, devices and formats.
As expected, and as we highlighted in our last quarterly call, we had nearly a 2 points drag on revenue from the partisan our other Watch bucket, we divested in our business late in the fourth quarter and you should also note in our filings in GAAP income loss that we realized an $18 million nonoperating gain on the transaction.
Our growth initiatives are delivering. Digital Ad Ratings continued its momentum, reflecting strong demand from advertisers, agencies and media owners. Digital Ad Ratings is an important offering in our Total Audience Measurement framework. And in 2015, our revenue nearly doubled as we added new clients and existing clients increased the number of campaigns versus a year-ago. Our subscription Video On Demand and Digital Content Ratings products continued to gain traction with our clients, giving us tremendous confidence and momentum heading into 2016.
Watch adjusted EBITDA was $340 million -- $343 million, up 6.9% on a constant currency basis. Watch margins expanded a strong 7 basis points on a constant currency basis as we continue to drive operating leverage in the business. Our Watch segment remains strong. We have executed a Total Audience Measurement, invested to transform the portfolio, our new products and initiatives are gaining momentum. 
Turning to Buy, our business had a strong fourth quarter and a solid year in 2015. Fourth quarter total Buy revenue was $879 million, up 5.9% on a constant currency basis. Our business in the developed markets was $607 million, up 4.8% on a constant currency basis behind relative strength in the U.S. and Europe. In addition, we saw some onetime discretionary spend pickup that led to a really strong quarter and finish to the year. 
Our business in the emerging markets was $272 million, up 8.4% on a constant currency basis. Our teams are executing against the tough backdrop of challenging macroeconomic conditions. We saw broad-based growth in the emerging markets, with double-digit growth in Latin America, the Middle East and Greater China, along with high single digits in Africa. Emerging market revenue grew 8.5% in 2015 and I'm very pleased with our team's execution in these markets.
Buy EBITDA, was $195 million, up 7.1% constant currency. Our Buy adjusted EBITDA margins were up 25 basis points in the quarter. This is the sixth straight quarter of Buy margin expansion as we have worked to improve profitability, while we continue to invest in our products and expand coverage in the emerging markets. Overall, we had a great quarter in Buy, with solid revenue growth and margin expansion on a constant currency basis.
Moving to foreign currency impact. I want to remind you that we report revenue and EBITDA on a constant currency basis to reflect our operating performance. We generally don't take on transactional risk, so this slide focuses strictly on the translation impact for reporting purposes. 
In the quarter, foreign currency resulted in a 620 basis point drag on revenue and a 500 basis point -- 580 basis points drag on EBITDA, which represented $0.02 of share earnings headwind versus our third quarter earnings call. For 2015, foreign currency impacted our adjusted net income per share results by $0.21. 
At yesterday's spot rates held constant in 2016, and we expect a 210 basis points drag on revenue and 140 basis points drag on EBITDA for the full year in 2016, which represents an incremental $0.02 a share drag on adjusted net income per share guidance that we gave in December. 
Moving to 2016 guidance. We are maintaining our 2016 earnings per share guidance despite an additional $0.02 headwind from FX. We remain confident in our plan to execute and deliver on all the operational elements that we laid out in December. 
So to wrap up, we're very pleased with our execution in the fourth quarter and 2015. We have a lot of confidence and momentum in both of our segments as we head into 2016. And in addition, we are committed to an efficient and balanced capital structure that will enable us to grow our business and return over $800 million in cash back to shareholders in 2016 in the form of dividends and buybacks. 
And with that, I'll turn it back to Kate.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Toni Kaplan with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Toni Kaplan with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Audience Measurement really strong this quarter, even with audio down more than expected. Can you just give us some additional color on what drove the core growth, was it Digital Ad Ratings or was it something else? And if you could give us your updated t
componenttext: Audience Measurement really strong this quarter, even with audio down more than expected. Can you just give us some additional color on what drove the core growth, was it Digital Ad Ratings or was it something else? And if you could give us your updated thoughts on the total addressable market for digital, that would be really great?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start and then Jamere, you can add. Toni, one thing I mentioned is that we're seeing, not only the normal strong growth that we have with our traditional clients, but also, we've seen accelerated growth with some of the Digital clients that we'
componenttext: Well, I'll start and then Jamere, you can add. Toni, one thing I mentioned is that we're seeing, not only the normal strong growth that we have with our traditional clients, but also, we've seen accelerated growth with some of the Digital clients that we're working with pretty broad range in marketplace. I mentioned Google and Facebook, but there's a number of others. One of the areas that has been long been a strength -- a strong growth for us in this areas is our work with the ad tech world, the ad exchanges, the add platforms where our Digital Ad Ratings metric, in particularly, has played very well. But also as we bring eXelate into the picture, it just raises our game in that area and so that's contributed. Jamere?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as we mentioned, the core of our business remains very strong. If you look at Audience Measurement in the quarter, which we're now calling Audience Measurement of video and text, it was up 7.6%. Now, recall, in the third quarter, we guided to a nu
componenttext: Yes. So as we mentioned, the core of our business remains very strong. If you look at Audience Measurement in the quarter, which we're now calling Audience Measurement of video and text, it was up 7.6%. Now, recall, in the third quarter, we guided to a number that was in the 4% to 4.5% range, we came in a little bit higher than that in the quarter. And the difference there are 2 things. One, the NTS joint venture, majority stake closed a little bit sooner than we had anticipated and energy closed a little bit later than we anticipated and it a result of that, we were up about 1 point. And then I think your last question was on -- just to finish up your last question was on the total opportunity as it relates to Digital. Back a couple of years ago, we said that this was potentially a $500 million market opportunity. We still see that as being the case. And we're in the early innings of that, obviously, but we're very confident in the products that we have a the marketplace and the adoption that we're seeing from our clients.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tim McHugh with William Blair.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tim McHugh with William Blair.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could just elaborate a little bit more on U.S. and Europe, parts of the Buy segments, I guess, I know you said new client wins and you talked a little bit about that. But what's resonating with clients? And how much of that is a mac
componenttext: I was wondering if you could just elaborate a little bit more on U.S. and Europe, parts of the Buy segments, I guess, I know you said new client wins and you talked a little bit about that. But what's resonating with clients? And how much of that is a macro indication of the activity there? And I guess in the context of what you see or hear from them as you come into 2016 year?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jamere. So a couple of things. One, we the discretionary spend environment has been pretty stable. We see our clients investing and analytics and innovation to help them drive top line growth and you've seen from a number of CPG clients as th
componenttext: Yes, this is Jamere. So a couple of things. One, we the discretionary spend environment has been pretty stable. We see our clients investing and analytics and innovation to help them drive top line growth and you've seen from a number of CPG clients as they come out of the restructuring cycle, that they're pivoting to grow by investing in innovation. So the U.S. for us was up low single digits in the fourth quarter, but up mid-single digits for 2015. And in Western Europe, we saw our business being up mid-single digits behind strong results from new client wins and innovation. So we feel very good about where we are in the cycle and our clients are starting to see some growth.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just add that we had mentioned some of these client wins. We don't mention them all. We have a lot more that -- than what we mentioned. We don't always get the full support of our clients to broadcast these on these calls, but some that we have menti
componenttext: I'll just add that we had mentioned some of these client wins. We don't mention them all. We have a lot more that -- than what we mentioned. We don't always get the full support of our clients to broadcast these on these calls, but some that we have mentioned in previous calls Reckitt Benckiser as RB and Cody, obviously play into it. And on this call, we mentioned Dole Foods earlier. Retailers, is another thing I would call out. We increased our focus on retailers over the past year. This is a global opportunity for our business. But in particular, an important opportunity for us in developed markets where retailer environment is a a little more consolidated and so their profile in the market is raised. And what we find is that, while retailers have long been data partners for Nielsen and also been long clients of our capabilities, both measurement and analytics, their need for the analytics capabilities we have has been growing in recent years to help them with their pricing and their there merchandising. And now, more recently, we're seeing their needs for our Watch assets to help them with their advertising decisions growing as well and the big advertisers as you well know. And so retailers has been an important part of our Buy business growth and in particular, in developed markets. NVC very, very strong opportunity for our business with retailers going forward. In fact, if we would size it going forward, we would say that they represent as much as 0.5 point of kind of growth for our business over the next 3 to 5 years, 0.5 point per year over the next 3 to 5 years at a global level, that's how significant the opportunity we see with retailers is.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Dan Salmon with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Dan Salmon with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mitch, you mentioned before that the strength in the Watch side was being helped by DAR's deeper penetration into the programmatic marketplace. I'm curious, how much is eXelate helping open up those conversations for you? And would you consider those -- m
componenttext: Mitch, you mentioned before that the strength in the Watch side was being helped by DAR's deeper penetration into the programmatic marketplace. I'm curious, how much is eXelate helping open up those conversations for you? And would you consider those -- most of those clients to fall in the sort of small- and medium-sized clients bucket? And then sort of separate but relatedly, is eXelate helping you open up conversations with larger clients as well that could be in the ad tech space, I know you mentioned publicly Google being a growing client of yours, but maybe even in other parts of the business where eXelate is opening up large client conversations?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great question. I think what's implied by your question is exactly what our experience had been. The big clients, the small clients, this is an ecosystem that is as connected as any other that we work in across our business around the world and i
componenttext: That's a great question. I think what's implied by your question is exactly what our experience had been. The big clients, the small clients, this is an ecosystem that is as connected as any other that we work in across our business around the world and it eXelate has helped us on every front. First, credibility. They have amazing talent. They have proven very strong capabilities. Those, now being part of Nielsen portfolio gives us more credibility in this area than we otherwise would have had, how we just continued on the path that we were on. We also bring a lot to the party by connecting with Nielsen historically has and developing recent years with eXelate but they bring into our portfolio has just accelerated our progress, with the both small and with the larger players because, again, they're all connected in some level. It's not just coincidence that Google has emerged over the past year or so to be one of our largest Watch clients in the world. And so it really speaks to what underlies your question. So again, we feel great about the eXelate acquisition. The business itself that we acquired performed incredibly well in 2015. But even beyond that business, at P&L, it's the asset and that talent came into Nielsen that are contributing all across our portfolio that we're also seeing good value from that. Jamere, you have something to add?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The thing that really stands out to us and the reason we're so excited about the acquisition is that every client that we work with on both the Watch and the buy side of our business is looking for accurate data to target the right audience. And we h
componenttext: Yes. The thing that really stands out to us and the reason we're so excited about the acquisition is that every client that we work with on both the Watch and the buy side of our business is looking for accurate data to target the right audience. And we have these relationships with over 200 online data providers and we're working with over 125 media platforms. So we're in all of the right conversations and we have an opportunity to address both large and small audiences just based on the footprint and capabilities inside this business.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Meuler with Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Meuler with Baird.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know you guys and the past have highlighted some video audience measurement clients of the are not at the support, can you just talk a bit more how they use Nielsen data? And then do they pay you similar rates for rating their content as nonad supported
componenttext: I know you guys and the past have highlighted some video audience measurement clients of the are not at the support, can you just talk a bit more how they use Nielsen data? And then do they pay you similar rates for rating their content as nonad supported plan, as supported clients?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we're doing in this area is, with respect to measurements of VOD, both ad-supported and subscription-based, is really serving the entire market, whether it's one of those platforms who is the source of that video content or whether it's a netwo
componenttext: Well, what we're doing in this area is, with respect to measurements of VOD, both ad-supported and subscription-based, is really serving the entire market, whether it's one of those platforms who is the source of that video content or whether it's a network or studio who might be licensing that content to the same platform. So we've made these VOD measurement capabilities available, both VOD viewed through the cable or telco satellite providers set-top box, as well as VOD viewed over-the-top, if you will, so connected device. And we're measuring all of those have different ways the consumers watch this content. I mentioned earlier, we're now covering more than 6,000 different program episodes in the marketplace and serving a wide range of clients as we do that. And yes, so sometimes it is the original owner of that content who wants to make sure that they're licensing it to that platform for a fee that's consistent with what its value is given the size of the audience and the appetite for that content. And in some cases, yes, it might be a studio who's producing it or other player. So we're really serving a much broader range of needs and much broader range of clients than just the original source of that content itself, the platform itself. In some cases, platform might say, well, look, I already have a lot of data about how much viewing is happening on my platform. They may not feel a great need for what Nielsen brings to the party there, and that's okay. We respect that. But there's 2 other players who would like to content for them who do want more information about how much viewing is happening and how much it compare with the other places that they might choose to license that content instead.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tom Eagan with Telsey Advisory Advertising Group.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tom Eagan with Telsey Advisory Advertising Group.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on 2016 margins. Jamere, you had mentioned at Analyst Day that Buy margins would be a bigger contributor to overall margin growth in '16. Given the 50 to 70 basis point margin gain guidance, what does that mean for Watch margin '16? And then I
componenttext: A question on 2016 margins. Jamere, you had mentioned at Analyst Day that Buy margins would be a bigger contributor to overall margin growth in '16. Given the 50 to 70 basis point margin gain guidance, what does that mean for Watch margin '16? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. So we did give guidance for 50 to 70 basis point of margin expansion and that is on a total company basis and we do expect Buy to be a bigger contributor in 2016. The reason for that is really 2 key drivers. Number one, we're continuing to scale in
componenttext: Great. So we did give guidance for 50 to 70 basis point of margin expansion and that is on a total company basis and we do expect Buy to be a bigger contributor in 2016. The reason for that is really 2 key drivers. Number one, we're continuing to scale in the emerging markets and we have a focus on profitability. And as those investments that we made in the emerging markets continue to; scale, then Buy margins are moving in the right direction. You see Buy margins expand over the last 6 quarters and we expect that to continue into 2016. And Then the second dynamic is that, with intensity around cost and productivity, we've done that for a number of years. We're going to continue to that in 2016. So we feel good about the 50 to 70 basis point of margin expansion in the company and we expect Buy to be a bigger contributor. In terms of Watch in 2016, 2016 is an investment year for us as we look to roll out our new product capabilities and that investment isn't necessarily in sort of the traditional OpEx that you would expect. But we're going to add a lot of commercial capabilities to help us to go after the growth opportunities with digital clients. And so you're going to expect margins to be positive in Watch and we're going to manage the total company to 50 to 70 basis point and you're going to expect Buy to be a bigger contributor in 2016.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Secondly, I had a question for potential for CPM deflation. One concern I've heard from TV networks about combining linear and digitally video ratings is that there's a prospect for CPM deflation, meaning the higher CPM of digital video declining t
componenttext: Great. Secondly, I had a question for potential for CPM deflation. One concern I've heard from TV networks about combining linear and digitally video ratings is that there's a prospect for CPM deflation, meaning the higher CPM of digital video declining to the linear CPM. So any thoughts you have on how can this be avoided, would be great?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's common conversation in the industry. And I think there are some things that will counter that. So we'll see some forces that will push at that direction. We'll see other forces that will counterbalance that and one of them is precision. Becaus
componenttext: Yes, that's common conversation in the industry. And I think there are some things that will counter that. So we'll see some forces that will push at that direction. We'll see other forces that will counterbalance that and one of them is precision. Because you have this -- all these datasets that are being connected, great tools being built by Nielsen and others from an analytics capability that enable more and more precision, not only in the digital world, but even in the linear world going forward. And that increased precision means less waste in terms of advertising exposures to people pay for and that will be a positive driver on costs -- on CPMs. In addition, I think we're also continuing to see people realize the importance of reach. While you can get incredible precision sometimes in the digital world, it's hard to have that and reach at the same time. And that's one of the reasons why  linear television continues to hold up, so well even with all the forces trying to pull viewers away. Linear television still delivers incredible reach in the marketplace. And advertisers know that reach deserves a premium in terms of getting their advertising message out the brand. The first exposure of my ad to a consumer is the best 1 and e reach is what I really am seeking for, first and foremost, and that's the only that first and foremost, and so that will be a second positive force that will continue to support the evolution of these CPMs in the marketplace. So some plusses and minuses, we'll see where it plays out, however it plays out.  Our Total Audience Measurement system will not measure it, but enlighten people to what they're actually getting in the marketplace and how this compare with what they have to get when they planned.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Andrew Steinerman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Andrew Steinerman with JPMorgan.

componenttext: So on your second question on NCS JV, it went from 50% to 63.5%. And then if you look at the pieces in terms of organic, we've had about 1.5 point in the quarter, the team from NCS and eXelate, pieces in the Watch business and then you had in the Buy business, from an organic standpoint in the quarter.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sara Gubins from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there anything that you saw in late fourth quarter, early first quarter that makes you think that you'd be at the higher or lower end of the ranges that you've given in some of the segment details at the Investor Day? As an example, 30% growth at Marke
componenttext: Is there anything that you saw in late fourth quarter, early first quarter that makes you think that you'd be at the higher or lower end of the ranges that you've given in some of the segment details at the Investor Day? As an example, 30% growth at Marketing Effectiveness, the guidance for next year's calling for 15% to 20% and so I look at that and wonder if you're at a more comfortable at the higher-end, but it's a broader question across both Watch and Buy?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So just to remind you on marketing effectiveness, we said in the third quarter that we saw some work push out from third quarter to the fourth quarter and you saw that play out in our numbers, this is why we had a growth rate number that is higher th
componenttext: Yes. So just to remind you on marketing effectiveness, we said in the third quarter that we saw some work push out from third quarter to the fourth quarter and you saw that play out in our numbers, this is why we had a growth rate number that is higher than sort of high end of the range that gave. But we feel pretty good about what we gave at Analyst Day and we're seeing trends in the fourth quarter and early in the first quarter, line up very nicely with the ranges that we gave and we reaffirmed the guidance accordingly.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And [indiscernible] in the third quarter, Jamere, is around 8%, something like that?
componenttext: And [indiscernible] in the third quarter, Jamere, is around 8%, something like that?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, you saw Marketing Effectiveness at about 8%. And remember, Marketing Effectiveness, a portion of that is discretionary, a portion of that is subscription-based. And oftentimes, you may have some work that leads from one quarter to the other. We did
componenttext: Right, you saw Marketing Effectiveness at about 8%. And remember, Marketing Effectiveness, a portion of that is discretionary, a portion of that is subscription-based. And oftentimes, you may have some work that leads from one quarter to the other. We did get a little bit of a catch-up in the fourth quarter but still very strong on an overall basis. And we feel good about the range of 15% to 20% heading into next year.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so Sara, looking back to last year, 8% in the third quarter, a little bit more than 30% in the fourth quarter. Pretty -- if you add those 2 together, pretty similar to our growth of just a little bit more than 20% for the full year.
componenttext: And so Sara, looking back to last year, 8% in the third quarter, a little bit more than 30% in the fourth quarter. Pretty -- if you add those 2 together, pretty similar to our growth of just a little bit more than 20% for the full year.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bill Warmington with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bill Warmington with Wells Fargo.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first, just want to say thank you for the additional disclosure on the Watch segment. My question is around the increased ownership in Catalina. Why, and why now? And then also, do you feel that you have all the components necessary in terms of tying t
componenttext: So first, just want to say thank you for the additional disclosure on the Watch segment. My question is around the increased ownership in Catalina. Why, and why now? And then also, do you feel that you have all the components necessary in terms of tying together the Watch data and the point-of-sale data? And if not, what do you still need to add?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bill, I'll start off. Jamere can add. I mentioned it in my opening comments how we see this Nielsen Catalina Solutions business as being perfectly aligned with our strategy. So let's take a look what do they do. Well, they take information about what
componenttext: Yes, Bill, I'll start off. Jamere can add. I mentioned it in my opening comments how we see this Nielsen Catalina Solutions business as being perfectly aligned with our strategy. So let's take a look what do they do. Well, they take information about what consumers buy, they connect it with information about what consumers Watch, whether it's on television or in the digital world and therefore their advertising exposure, and then they put that data together to provide measurement and analytics capabilities to clients -- to help clients, first of all, find the right audiences for their advertising and, but also to access the ROI on that advertising. This is Nielsen. This is Nielsen, right at the heart of our business and so while we have enjoyed this very positive and productive partnership with cattle you now to put in this business together, this is really right on the core of our business. And so that's why we saw this as an something that we really, really want to secure the control controlling stake in going forward. You see us doing this business this way by the way, focuses primarily on FMCG brands, consumer packaged goods in the marketplace, we have similar capabilities our portfolio already with more to come that do pretty much the same thing and other verticals out there in the marketplace. So having that control and stake in this joint venture also allows us to develop at a bit more scale advantages as we develop a similar capabilities to serve other verticals.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now, listen, advertisers are asking the question on ROI and for the big-rated advertisers, ROI is the holy grail. And you also saw for the media companies last year in the upfront where they were taking, not only our meetings data, but also taking our Mar
componenttext: Now, listen, advertisers are asking the question on ROI and for the big-rated advertisers, ROI is the holy grail. And you also saw for the media companies last year in the upfront where they were taking, not only our meetings data, but also taking our Marketing Effectiveness products like Nielsen Buyer Insights and Nielsen Catalina Solutions, packaging those together to sort of amplify the value of their inventory. And so as those market dynamics play out, we see this as a fast-growing area of the business, and we said that we're going to continue to invest in the faster-growing, high margin pieces of the business and this is a great investment for us and we're looking forward to the growth prospects going forward.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's exciting what we're doing in this area and really what's happening in the industry overall. I've been around long enough to remember the days when people ask these questions about the ROI and their advertising spend and there was no answer. And so --
componenttext: It's exciting what we're doing in this area and really what's happening in the industry overall. I've been around long enough to remember the days when people ask these questions about the ROI and their advertising spend and there was no answer. And so -- then they just stopped asking the question. And here we are today, with the data sources available, the tools that enable us to put them together, these questions can be answered now. And that's why you see such strong, consistent growth in our Marketing Effectiveness business, 20% or more in 2015. Most of that coming, by the way, from developed markets. Because the capabilities are developing and accelerating so rapidly and there is strong demand from clients all across the marketplace for what Nielsen does in this area and for what others do. So we love what Nielsen Catalina Solutions brings to our portfolio. We love the opportunity now to make it more integrated and connected with a similar capabilities that we already have in the certain other verticals.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Juenger with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Juenger with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys mentioned a few times in your prepared remarks how your business model holds up so well up and down to the cycles. Would love it if you put just remind us going looking back, how Nielsen, the business, performed through the previous recession cyc
componenttext: You guys mentioned a few times in your prepared remarks how your business model holds up so well up and down to the cycles. Would love it if you put just remind us going looking back, how Nielsen, the business, performed through the previous recession cycles? And then thinking about the changes in your footprint in the marketplace, how might we expect your business to perform through the next down cycle that would be very helpful?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Todd, 38 consecutive quarters of constant currency revenue growth in our business. And if you draw the line back, that even goes through the big global economic downturn that occurred from late 2007 and through 2009. And it's a result of our business mode
componenttext: Todd, 38 consecutive quarters of constant currency revenue growth in our business. And if you draw the line back, that even goes through the big global economic downturn that occurred from late 2007 and through 2009. And it's a result of our business model. We're in 106 countries around the world. We serve a broad range of clients. We had a broad portfolio capabilities, many of which are must-have information for clients to run their business with. And in fact, they needed some of the kinds of things we do even more when economic conditions get difficult. And so we will shift our focus to those parts of our portfolio to become even more important when economic conditions grow more complicated or more challenging for our clients and that enables us to deliver this steady, consistent performance in our business around the world.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And if you look at our core revenue growth, 2008 to 2010, our core revenue grew 4.6% and again, that speaks to the consistency and resiliency of the Nielsen business model, and it's all the things that we counted for a number of years being in syndic
componenttext: Yes. And if you look at our core revenue growth, 2008 to 2010, our core revenue grew 4.6% and again, that speaks to the consistency and resiliency of the Nielsen business model, and it's all the things that we counted for a number of years being in syndicated businesses, long-term contracts that go 3 to 9 years, we get good pricing, our teams are doing a fantastic job and delivering on productivity through the cycles. And good cycles and better cycles of the attributes to this business olds holds a very, very well.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our focus on what ability is especially important here because we are always starting the year developing our own reserve for how to invest back into our business. We're not waiting for the growth to happen to create the opportunity to invest in the futur
componenttext: Our focus on what ability is especially important here because we are always starting the year developing our own reserve for how to invest back into our business. We're not waiting for the growth to happen to create the opportunity to invest in the future of our business. You always start with productivity. This has been a real strength of our company and I think it's one of the reasons why we move through more challenging economic conditions better than the other companies who operate in the same space that we do.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Manav Patnaik with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Manav Patnaik with Barclays.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan filling in for Manav. Just want to talk -- I know you don't report the Buy Insights business but I think generally, that's been a pretty good indicator of kind of the future expected growth in that part of the business. There's some concerns
componenttext: This is Ryan filling in for Manav. Just want to talk -- I know you don't report the Buy Insights business but I think generally, that's been a pretty good indicator of kind of the future expected growth in that part of the business. There's some concerns I guess that emerging markets are starting slowdown and particularly, China, you guys have called out in the past. Can you just touch on anything you're using in emerging markets and kind of a more discretionary based spend is looking for clients, particularly exiting the fourth quarter and in the beginning of the year just given some of the more choppiness we're seeing out there?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, thanks for mentioning, China. I always love talking China, my old home. Our business held up incredibly well in mainland China in 2015, double-digit growth even with what was happening in the financial markets and the market overall. I think the key
componenttext: Ryan, thanks for mentioning, China. I always love talking China, my old home. Our business held up incredibly well in mainland China in 2015, double-digit growth even with what was happening in the financial markets and the market overall. I think the key reason for that is in addition to our teams staying focused and exhibited will and in doing to gain penetration like I mentioned for our teams what they have done in Brazil, Russia, Turkey, China was very similar for us. The other thing as our core focus is on the consumer end up in supermarkets and retail sales and digital and other media consumption. The consumer focus of our business and in China, that is largely separate, frankly, from a lot of the tour mile that you've seen a differential markets, which has a dominated the press about the China market recently. And so I think those 2 things go to the for why we still had a strong year of double-digit growth in mainland China in 2015.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, listen, I'm encouraged because what I see is really broad-based growth. So if you look at Latin America, which is our largest region, was up double digits, with one of our largest markets, Brazil being up in the mid-teens. China, our second-largest r
componenttext: Yes, listen, I'm encouraged because what I see is really broad-based growth. So if you look at Latin America, which is our largest region, was up double digits, with one of our largest markets, Brazil being up in the mid-teens. China, our second-largest region, was up double digits in the fourth quarter. The Middle East was up double digits. Africa, which is our fastest-growing region is up single digits. So we've seen broad-based growth across the market. I think the other dynamic that really stands out for me is that in the emerging markets where multinational makeup about 65% of our business. We really did see them pivot the growth there over the last year or so. And emerging -- the growth in emerging markets for multi-nationals was about on par with what we've seen in locals where locals at one point were growing significant investor than the multinational. So broad-based growth and get health in really both segments of the market after him, so multinationals and locals.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to your question about insight to specifically, I prefer to think of it as the analytics portion of our business. Again, when the economic conditions be a little bit more difficult and clients are starting to look for direction and the analytics portf
componenttext: And to your question about insight to specifically, I prefer to think of it as the analytics portion of our business. Again, when the economic conditions be a little bit more difficult and clients are starting to look for direction and the analytics portfolio that we have is what gives a lot of those answers. So we'll help them pricing decision, we'll help them be more efficient with their assortment. We'll help them think differently about how they marketed to consumers to be more efficient with their marketing spend all of these kinds of things tap directly into our analytics portfolio, not to mention our analytics capabilities around new product conversation, which we continue to invest in and believe in the importance -- important role it plays in our business going forward.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Andrea Benjamin with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Andrea Benjamin with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know it's early going, but I was wondering if you could provide some color on what some of the more critical feedback has been so far with Digital Content Ratings and Total Audience, it's pretty easy to imagine what are the positive -- I'm sorry, given
componenttext: I know it's early going, but I was wondering if you could provide some color on what some of the more critical feedback has been so far with Digital Content Ratings and Total Audience, it's pretty easy to imagine what are the positive -- I'm sorry, given at the address and when should we expect sonication of those products and how much your total client base is currently testing them?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrea, we don't do negatives.
componenttext: Andrea, we don't do negatives.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll be happy to go in a little bit more detail on those. Andrea, thanks for the question. Digital Content Ratings, I mentioned earlier, the rollout is progressing well. We have a diverse range of clients, networks, MVPDs, publishers, number of them fully
componenttext: I'll be happy to go in a little bit more detail on those. Andrea, thanks for the question. Digital Content Ratings, I mentioned earlier, the rollout is progressing well. We have a diverse range of clients, networks, MVPDs, publishers, number of them fully operational already, more in process, soon to be operational. I mentioned, we hadn't made digital video player that will be added in the coming weeks, so excited about that. And also just growing engagement from the industry broadly, dozens of clients participating on our client advisory board. With regard to syndication of Digital Content Ratings, we said on our last call, in quarter 3, that we're on track for syndication in the first part of this year and we remain on track for syndication in the first part of this year. It's likely to be sometime in early to middle part of the second quarter. But we'll do that with the guidance from our clients in our upcoming client advisory board, will help us firm up. What is the right timing for our client. That's really where it starts and ends with us has to do it at the right time and the right way to best serve their needs in the market, so that's the Digital Content Ratings. And then total content ratings, Digital Content Ratings obviously flows into and plays a big part in total content ratings, along with the Audience Measurement we have linear television, video-on-demand and everything else. And we're well on track for syndication of total content rating as well. We would peg that one right around the end of the second quarter of the year right now. But we already have a 70-plus networks that are receiving data from total content ratings. And all of that, along with everything else from our Total Audience Measurement system is already informing and supporting our clients thinking and decision-making as they approach the 2016 upfront. So we already know it's being useful to the marketplace and we are absolutely thrilled about that. And one of the thing on total content ratings I think is, is just interesting to know it's. We did a recent analysis, a sampling of shareholders that we can see through total content ratings. And what we did is we looked that they ratings that you would get out of total content ratings and we compared it to the ratings you would get if you just looked at our Audience Measurement of linear television. In this case, there are number of people that saw it in your television either live or through a DVR for 7 days after the live viewing. So compare total content rating to linear television ratings, what we see that is in total content ratings, ratings are at leats 10% higher in most cases. And in some cases, as much as 50% higher. And so we know that this system is working, and it's really showing the broader range and the lift that's available to clients in the industry as they contemplate how to redefine the currency, what to include in that new definition of a currency, which is, of course, the focus of those ongoing client discussions and meetings that I referred to earlier. So to excited where this is going to go in the marketplace is exciting to see the role that our Total Audience Measurement system is playing in all of it.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Wieser with Pivotal Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Wieser with Pivotal Research.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Brian Wieser here. 2, I have. First, there seems to be a fair amount of misinformation even among the CEOs of some of your clients around some elements of your data and to the extent that they've been on what seem to be a tax on credibility of the da
componenttext: It's Brian Wieser here. 2, I have. First, there seems to be a fair amount of misinformation even among the CEOs of some of your clients around some elements of your data and to the extent that they've been on what seem to be a tax on credibility of the data in some ways, it makes me wonder what you're doing to address it, those attacks in the public sphere. I understand you can't necessarily correct your clients as much as maybe might be appropriate or might be needed. But appears about how you're thinking about that dynamic in general? Separately, I saw you recently signed [indiscernible] Media General and, of course, I think you signed [indiscernible] tribute last year on the local side. I'm just curious how that terms of your deals with the local station groups are evolving in terms of term lengths, price escalators, product extensions or otherwise?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks Brian, great questions. First on the comments and criticism sometimes that we'll hear from our clients in the marketplace. We understand that, first of all, what would -- what I take from it very initially is, is always positive when our class
componenttext: Yes, thanks Brian, great questions. First on the comments and criticism sometimes that we'll hear from our clients in the marketplace. We understand that, first of all, what would -- what I take from it very initially is, is always positive when our class our topics all about the marketplace what is a since we are highly relevant, and that's always a good thing. But of course, I prefer that there is a good things as opposed to criticisms, but they are making criticisms, we listen, this the first erupted on we have to ask ourselves is, is that criticism invalid or is that based on misinformation or maybe incomplete information and then we respond accordingly. And what we almost always do is when we hear a comment like this in the market is, we follow up and be follow-up and we say, would like to understand we saw our heard what he said, would like to understand a little bit more about why you said at that and that often give it gives us a case to bring that particular client up-to-date on something, it gives us a chance to make our case on something and in some cases, it gives us a chance to learn and we get better from that. So it's always productive and when we respond to it in the right way, and we've been very focus on doing exactly that in the past year and we're going to continue that in the year ahead. And while we never expect those kinds of comments to go away entirely, we do see and we have heard others say that we're making progress on that front. And so we feel good about that. We're going to stay focused on it. On your other question about [indiscernible] and Media General, you also mentioned the St. Clair and Tribune, we're thrilled, whether it's a client who's signing a contract with us for the first time or whether it's the 50th time, we're always thrilled by those and so the renewals here that are happening in our local television business in to really are when was are just that. And in terms, reflect where we are in this part of the business local television business has been over the last several years that trend has been low single-digit growth and of the contract reflect that and are consistent with the that. What you're also seeing Bill with, for instance, the Hertz renewal, recently is it's not just focused on local television, then your television manage measurement also starting to tap increasingly into the broader range of capability you can bring for them both for digital measurement and also for analytics that have of them better sell of their ad inventory to their advertiser clients in the marketplace. And so we're seeing these relationships broaden a bit, utilize Moravec of abilities we bring to the marketplace, that's a big positive.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is about Total Audience Measurement and I wondered if you could help me I'm thinking about this the right way. Back in the day, Nielsen TV ratings were basically the only way for a TV network to monetize advertising. Now there are other ways.
componenttext: My question is about Total Audience Measurement and I wondered if you could help me I'm thinking about this the right way. Back in the day, Nielsen TV ratings were basically the only way for a TV network to monetize advertising. Now there are other ways. There are competitors to some degree, TV networks that have their own apps can collect their own data any of had, so my question is I don't think anybody questions at the relevancy of Total Audience Measurement but is it possible to break down how the revenue streams may look as in will you sell Total Audience Measurement as a data source of the subscription as you ratings? And then is there a separate element of selling data with feeds into programmatic buying in changes. You just may understand how we should think about the Total Audience Measurement revenue stream. does that make sense?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does. I'll share a few thoughts on that and maybe Jamere has something to add. First, with regard to competitors or networks or publishers who have their own data, there are 2 things that bring that are highly depreciated versus anybody else out t
componenttext: Yes, it does. I'll share a few thoughts on that and maybe Jamere has something to add. First, with regard to competitors or networks or publishers who have their own data, there are 2 things that bring that are highly depreciated versus anybody else out there. One is we bring a comprehensive view, especially when it comes to video, we're able to bring a full range of places and ways of the consumer's view video content, that's our Total Audience Measurement system, that what it's about. Nobody else has that comprehensive view with the level of quality granularity that we bring to the market, so that's one. And then the other is independence, which is incredibly important in the marketplace. For instance, digital publisher and I have my own data, I can share that with an advertiser. So that's great in terms of helping that advertiser understand what's possible on my particular platform. But what I can't put that in context relative to the rest of the options available to that advertiser and also not independent provider of that information and to sell advertisers ultimately want that independence so that things are looked at in the same way with objectivity, not only on that particular publisher's platform, but across other platforms. And to your point about the description versus maybe more volume are based as it might be more typical these days in the ad tech wrote and then there's other dimension, which is measurement versus analytics yes, I think that's exactly consistent with our experience over the past few years. We see a wider range of a business models and expressing the way we've contracted with or engaged with our clients. And part of that businesses the state of fragmentation in the base of a change in the industry and the likely will converge to be a nod our range of this models going forward. But it tougher for a clientele that flexibility right now as everything is changing, so fast and in marketplace. For instance, if I'm going to sign up for a fee-based service, then I need to know whether or not I'm going to really get the value out of that fee-based service over that was of the year that maybe multiple years of that contract applies to. But if it's a something that's emerging in the marketplace rapidly, it's kind of hard to know where it's going to be at year or 2 or 3 years down the road, so I might prefer to instead decide of for more of volume abased contract right now because I don't know if it's going to be 2x bigger next year or 5x or 10x bigger next year, so volume base would be a better way to contract. And we offer that kind of flexibility to our clients and I think that serves us well. Jamere, anything to add?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just a couple of things. One, today, we have the ratings data on a subscription basis, but we sell datasets into agencies and programmatic networks today. And so that model will continue in the future. In terms of the way contracts will be structured
componenttext: Yes, just a couple of things. One, today, we have the ratings data on a subscription basis, but we sell datasets into agencies and programmatic networks today. And so that model will continue in the future. In terms of the way contracts will be structured, we anticipate having our large media clients continuing to do there with us but we are also signing up a number of native digital clients and those are all-new clients for us and new opportunities to grow our business. Asset mix said, we are pretty flexible in terms of the business model. But we will continue to see how consistent, steady long-term chronic contract with our big clients and we are signing up new native digital clients and we are pumping data in the programmatic networks today ominously through our eXelate acquisition.

So as you continue to build scale in those markets and you get our margins to move in the right direction. So we still have some runway in terms of margins inside Buy, and it's their recent bill conference going forward that our Buy margins will continue to expand in 2016.
