componenttext: Thanks. Operator, we'll take the first question.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from the line of Toni Kaplan from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from the line of Toni Kaplan from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Buy growth in developed markets I guess was the lowest since you started reporting it as a sub segment and clearly driven by this -- the Insights piece. So you've mentioned the secular shift away from customer insights to everyday analytics, and so I was
componenttext: Buy growth in developed markets I guess was the lowest since you started reporting it as a sub segment and clearly driven by this -- the Insights piece. So you've mentioned the secular shift away from customer insights to everyday analytics, and so I was hoping you could give a little more color on the drivers behind sort of the reduced spending. Are you losing shares, the competitive environment changing or are customers just tightening budgets? And is there any way to quantify that? And basically in terms of the investments that you're going to be making in Buy to address the shift, how much of this impact by margins?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Toni, let me start and I'm sure Jamere will add. First, with regard to Buy develop, yes, that is the challenging spot for our business in the quarter. But I would even narrow it further for you, because within Buy developed, Europe grew, the Pacif
componenttext: Thanks, Toni, let me start and I'm sure Jamere will add. First, with regard to Buy develop, yes, that is the challenging spot for our business in the quarter. But I would even narrow it further for you, because within Buy developed, Europe grew, the Pacific were, Canada grew. It's really the U.S, where the problem is focused at the moment. And so just to sharpen the focus a little bit, focus on the U.S. What we're seeing in the U.S. market, let me give you a couple of examples in terms of the external environment that our clients are dealing with. First, if you just focus in on food and beverage manufacturers. 2015, we saw this trend starting to emerge where the small and medium-sized manufacturers accounted for about half of the growth in the categories. And private label accounted for about 1/4 of the growth. And the big -- the top 25 players, they accounted collectively for only 3% of the growth in food and beverage categories in 2015. And that situation really hasn't changed that much in 2016. The reason why that's especially noteworthy for our business is the strength of our business just so happens to be the biggest global companies, the biggest global players. And so you see that reflected in our U.S. results. What all these companies are dealing with, both food and beverage and others, is a combination of things, product segmentation where consumers are increasingly shifting their purchasing to smaller, specialty, more niche products, moving away a little bit from the bigger brands. You see retail fragmentations to purchases moving across additional channels. Of course, see the 3G effect sweeping through the fast-moving consumer goods industry, where companies, whether 3G as a factor o r not are practicing zero-based budgeting. They're running the room internal 3G play. And you add up all these things together, and that's the situation that our clients are contending with, and you see that reflected back in our results. Now, for us, what that means in terms of their discretionary spend, as I said, they're shifting from these more deep dive projects that help them think about what they are going to do next year and focus much more on these every day analytics that help them with activation. What should I do today or tomorrow or this week? And that's where the shift is happening in the marketplace. And so we're realigning our portfolio to better serve those clients' interest, and those client needs. And as I mentioned, we don't see this as just a passing phase that the market place is going to. We see this as a trend that will continue on more of a secular basis over the long run. As we make this shift and as we build out this connected system, you see us building a very different business, really, frankly. Right now, it's very much a Professional Services model for Nielsen. As that connected system starts to unfold as a marketplace, it helps us to move from a professional service or people as a service business model to much more as data as a service and Software-as-a-Service business model, and that all results in, as Jamere said in his opening comments, having a stronger, higher-margin business. Jamere, what would you add?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of things on margin. You did see our margins dipped in the quarter. I would say the key drivers, as I said in my comments, were a bit of a mix issue as the emerging markets revenue grew 8.5% and the higher-margin developed markets revenue ac
componenttext: Just a couple of things on margin. You did see our margins dipped in the quarter. I would say the key drivers, as I said in my comments, were a bit of a mix issue as the emerging markets revenue grew 8.5% and the higher-margin developed markets revenue actually declined. The second thing, as I said, we're continuing to invest in the connected system and our total consumer initiatives to future-proof the business. And so on the short-term, with software revenue profile, this obviously puts pressure on margins. But in terms of our long-term productivity drivers, I would say 3 things. One is we are continuing to see scale benefits in the emerging markets, and there's a focus on profitability. We're running the place with intensity around cost and productivity, as I mentioned before, that we have over 4,000 projects that are running inside the company. We invested in our products, our higher-margin products. And I'd say the last thing is you've seen us take a couple of rounds of restructuring in the second quarter and the third quarter to put us on the right trajectory going forward. We have confidence again that we will expand margins on a total company basis and we're running all the right plays inside the company to be able to achieve that.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Juenger with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Juenger with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Probably unsurprisingly, I'll use my 1 question to dive a little bit further back into this topic again, if you don't mind. Let me take a shot and see you comment anything to help us size this a little bit. You used to disclose the insight line item or an
componenttext: Probably unsurprisingly, I'll use my 1 question to dive a little bit further back into this topic again, if you don't mind. Let me take a shot and see you comment anything to help us size this a little bit. You used to disclose the insight line item or analytics line item, the Buy segment, I  think the last you did that was 2014, and at that point in time, I think it was about 25% of Buy segment revenue. So I guess a question is, is that any reason to think that it's not sort of similar to that today? Any comments you'd make on, so the relative margin profile of that part of the business compared to the segment overall margin profile. And then as we think about what part of that is at risk, can you help us through, with all of that revenue pull at risk, some of that risk, as you transition to replacing it with this other shape of revenue and just helping to size it that way, whatever you help us say will be really helpful.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in terms of the size of what I will call our analytics or discretionary business, it is probably in the 30 percent-ish kind of range in terms of our total portfolio, sometimes a little bit more, a little bit less on a quarter basis just dependent
componenttext: Yes. So in terms of the size of what I will call our analytics or discretionary business, it is probably in the 30 percent-ish kind of range in terms of our total portfolio, sometimes a little bit more, a little bit less on a quarter basis just dependent on what the project pipeline is. I would say a couple of things. First of all, from in terms of what the focus area is in our portfolio is, there's probably 3% to 4% of the Buy revenue that is, as Mitch mentioned, slow-growing or becoming non-core. And as a couple of examples, if you look at a year ago, we will provide the data and analytics for things like helping retailers optimize store locations in a world where bricks and mortar is under pressure and e-commerce is actually growing, we will provide the data and analytics around video sales and retail channels in an environment where consumers are moving to more screen and digital consumption, providing data and analytics around alcoholic beverages moving through wholesalers channels. So giving some examples of a very broad portfolio Buy. And as we look at our resource allocation, as we look at the discretionary nature of some of those data sets and those analytics, we're actually going to move away from some of those. So it's 3% to 4% of the portfolio, and we're going to be aggressive about that and replace that with things that are more future-proof and things that are actually in our connected Buy system platform,  if you will. Now in terms of the margin profile, the analytics or ad hoc or discretionary projects have tended to be a lower margin profile than the overall business. And so as we think about moving forward in our future to a connected Buy system that is much more data as a service or people as a service oriented and the margin profile will certainly approve overall for the Buy business.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I'll add to that, Todd, is when we look at all the different analytics in as you describe them insight type capabilities we have in our portfolio, some of them are still doing incredibly well. And we see a pattern in terms of which parts are performi
componenttext: What I'll add to that, Todd, is when we look at all the different analytics in as you describe them insight type capabilities we have in our portfolio, some of them are still doing incredibly well. And we see a pattern in terms of which parts are performing better versus which ones are struggling in the current environment. And here's the characteristics of the things that are doing well. If the analytics capability is connected to our core measurement data, that's a positive. Second, if it is more focused on activation or these everyday analytics kind of questions, that's a positive. And third, if the talent required in that analytics area is similar to the talent that helps us to be successful in our core measurement business, that also tends to do better within the Nielsen portfolio. So we have a number of analytics capabilities that perfectly fit that profile surprise those are the parts that are performing really well. And then we have a number of others that don't fit that profile, and those are the ones where we have some decisions to make, and we've already started to take those decision as Jamere recounted. One of the things that I'll add to this picture, which I hope will be helpful, Todd, is why you might be wondering, what is the showing up or the U.S. than it is in other places? Well, the fact is the U.S. revenues, a bigger percentage of our U.S. revenues are these discretionary services. In fact, there's about twice as much, slightly more than twice as much of our U.S. revenues come from the discretionary services as compared to Europe we're much smaller percentage. So that's why you see it showing up in the U.S., and that's why our focus is currently centered on the U.S., but we're transforming our Buy portfolio really for the entire developed market wheel, then ultimately, a lot of these moves that we're making in particular with a connected system will benefit our business in the key emerging markets as well.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Tim McHugh from William Blair.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Tim McHugh from William Blair.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one more on this topic, I guess. You talked about for connected Buy the kind of the time line, but I guess what pace do you -- or how long will it take to kind of make this transition in the areas where you're just kind of moving away from the busine
componenttext: Just one more on this topic, I guess. You talked about for connected Buy the kind of the time line, but I guess what pace do you -- or how long will it take to kind of make this transition in the areas where you're just kind of moving away from the business over time, I guess? How long will this? Do you had one how quickly do you want to kind of move away from those areas?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The last thing we want to do is set excavations too aggressively. The timeline I described in my opening comments, I think it's exactly the right way to think about it, which is -- first of all, let me start with we already have the initial version of thi
componenttext: The last thing we want to do is set excavations too aggressively. The timeline I described in my opening comments, I think it's exactly the right way to think about it, which is -- first of all, let me start with we already have the initial version of this system built and in the hands of 5 initial clients. So I want you to just realize that this is real, and it's something we've been working on now for the better part of the year and even before Analyst Day last December when we first talked about this with our investors and analysts. We already have it in the hands of 5 initial clients. We have live modules that are already usable. We demonstrated those for our clients. And we have great feedback so far. In fact, our clients are already thinking through what it's going to mean in terms of implementation on their side, that's the kind of reaction we've received so far. We'll roll it out to 20 to 30 additional clients by the middle of 2017. And by the end of the year is when we think we'll be prepared for a more full rollout to all clients who want to start to make the shift and transition to this connected system. So we are certainly hopeful that it'll start to have some impact on our business in 2017, but I think the better way to think about it is it'll start to show up meaningfully, significantly in our business, especially the financial results in the 2018 timeframe. One more thing to add to that, just to put maybe a reference point on that. I mentioned in my opening comments, but I think it's exactly the right way to think about it. While it's a slightly different system that we're building and a slightly different set of client needs that we are addressing, the magnitude of this and the execution required to do it properly, to do it in a way that really fits with what our clients need, it's very similar to what we've seen us work successfully through on the Watch side of our business to develop the Total Audience Measurement framework and roll that out to our clients over the past couple of years. So look, we know how to do this. We have the teams in place, and they're very focused and excited about the task in front of them. And we have a huge opportunity to drive this stronger, higher-margin business for our future, to take cost out of our clients business on their side of the table, and we give them a lot more value and a lot more speed.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Manav Patnaik with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Manav Patnaik with Barclays.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to I guess again [indiscernible] Buy here, but in terms of the sequential changes you've seen, because you know the revenue backdrop you described doesn't seem that new. The margin investments in connected and the total device system that
componenttext: So I just wanted to I guess again [indiscernible] Buy here, but in terms of the sequential changes you've seen, because you know the revenue backdrop you described doesn't seem that new. The margin investments in connected and the total device system that isn't new as well. So in a q-over-q, what really changed, especially since I think you maybe just said the analytics side, it said was lower margins, so I would assume you have the flex to sort of offset that. So I'm just a little bit confused, quite honestly, on what changed over the quarter.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so a couple of things. First of all, if you're looking back to the third quarter last year, you saw our developed markets business grow 4.8% constant currency. And as part of that discussion, we said that we saw a pretty strong discretionary environm
componenttext: Yes, so a couple of things. First of all, if you're looking back to the third quarter last year, you saw our developed markets business grow 4.8% constant currency. And as part of that discussion, we said that we saw a pretty strong discretionary environment. We have not seen that since then, as we look at our results in our developed Buy business sequentially been going in the other direction. And part of that is because that's stable or I would say the environment in the third quarter last year actually ran a little hot. I'd say that environment has slowly started to erode, and we're starting to see the dynamics that Mitch and I have discussed in the call today. From a margin standpoint, again, you have a couple of dynamics there. One is you have sort of the mix shift between our developed markets revenue and our emerging markets revenue, that certainly plays into the numbers. And the second thing as I said, we continue to invest in our growth initiatives and a softer revenue environment is going to feel that margin pressure. More importantly, we've taken the actions, if you will, that will put us on the right trajectory from a cost standpoint, first of all, as I said, a couple of rounds of restructuring that you saw in the second and the third quarter numbers, continue to work on our productivity initiatives, we're investing and actually emphasizing the faster-growing higher-margin pieces of the Buy portfolio. And so we have a lot of confidence around that story and what that will mean for us going forward.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what I'll add to that as we said, you're right, it's not new, but we've always viewed this part of the business as lumpy. And so some quarters up, some quarters down. I think what it comes down to is we're just not thinking of it so much that way. Som
componenttext: And what I'll add to that as we said, you're right, it's not new, but we've always viewed this part of the business as lumpy. And so some quarters up, some quarters down. I think what it comes down to is we're just not thinking of it so much that way. Some of these characteristics, we're not viewing as lumpiness. We are, as I said, seeing more secular shifts. And so we've just reached that conclusion that it's not viable for the long term to keep running after these short-term revenue opportunities and keep trying to chase these and work our way through the lumpy nature of this part of our business. Instead, a much better future is about investing in something that transforms our product portfolio, that takes some of the lumpiness out of this part of our business, that benefits with what our clients need and where their needs are evolving toward, and that's what connected system is designed to do. And so we're not running after the short-term revenue opportunities as much in the quarter and that will continue going forward, and that allows us to reallocate, enables us to reallocate resources to build faster and do more as we develop this connected system in this. And so you see all of that reflected in the results in the quarter and outlook going forward.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Kip Paulson from Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Kip Paulson from Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple from me. Starting with Watch, Marketing Effectiveness growth picked up nicely in the quarter. How much of this was driven by Marketing Cloud or eXelate versus Nielsen Catalina? And can you give us a sense of how fast Marketing Cloud is growi
componenttext: Just a couple from me. Starting with Watch, Marketing Effectiveness growth picked up nicely in the quarter. How much of this was driven by Marketing Cloud or eXelate versus Nielsen Catalina? And can you give us a sense of how fast Marketing Cloud is growing? I believe eXelate was growing at a roughly 40% clip a couple of quarters ago. And then second, if I could, how much of the $100 million reduction in the free cash flow guidance would you attribute to underperformance in developed Buy versus increased investment?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just to give you a little bit of color on our Marketing Effective business is up 31.8% in the quarter. As you know, we did have a couple of inorganic beings in there with Nielsen sports and Nielsen Catalina Solutions that is growing probably closer t
componenttext: Yes. Just to give you a little bit of color on our Marketing Effective business is up 31.8% in the quarter. As you know, we did have a couple of inorganic beings in there with Nielsen sports and Nielsen Catalina Solutions that is growing probably closer to an 18% organic number. The things that we're really excited about in Marketing Effectiveness, first of all, is the Nielsen Marketing Cloud or eXelate is up double digits. Nielsen viral Insights is up double digits, as clients continue to look for our data sets to help them build ROI solutions. And Nielsen Catalina Solutions is up about 18% organically as well. So we continue to be impressed with the growth that we are seeing in Marketing Effectiveness, and it's provided a nice tailwind for our business. In terms of the free cash flow outlook for the year, so just a couple of things. One is, as you alluded to, most of the sort of revenue shortfall actually is within our Buy business, so that's a big driver of it. So you've got a couple of things [indiscernible] to the numbers. One is reduced EBITDA outlook, particularly for the developed Buy regions. The second thing is that we are continuing to invest, and actually our investment profile is slightly higher than what we began at the beginning of the year, and that is a both a Watch and a Buy story. So on the Watch side, you'll see us acquire and begin integrate set-top box data for all the things that we're doing with our Total Audience Measurement initiatives. We've talked about moving away from the paper diaries and bringing more electronic measurement to the marketplace. That certainly roll into the numbers. And we have a big year front of us in terms of bringing DCR and DAR to the marketplace and growing that piece of the business. And then the last piece is growing the investment profile associated with our connected system and our total consumer initiatives. So combination of lower EBITDA expectations and the slightly higher investment profile for some of the key growth initiatives in the future is driving it. And then one other thing I'd add to that is we're probably going to be at the upper end of what we gave as sort of a cash restructuring number, and that's focused on the fact that in the second quarter and the third quarter, we've taken a couple of actions in our Buy business to set us on the right trajectory for the future. So those are the things that are driving the number from a free cash flow standpoint.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Wieser from Pivotal Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Wieser from Pivotal Research.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk about the grand total of organic growth for the quarter, just try to dimensionalize that. And maybe relatedly, was there any contribution on the organic side from DCR and TCR directly in the quarter?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk about the grand total of organic growth for the quarter, just try to dimensionalize that. And maybe relatedly, was there any contribution on the organic side from DCR and TCR directly in the quarter?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so from an organic standpoint, we had about a 1.5, just a little over -- a little under 1.5 of revenue contribution with the combination of Nielsen Catalina Solutions and Nielsen Sports Repucom offset by energy. Those are the numbers from an organic
componenttext: Yes, so from an organic standpoint, we had about a 1.5, just a little over -- a little under 1.5 of revenue contribution with the combination of Nielsen Catalina Solutions and Nielsen Sports Repucom offset by energy. Those are the numbers from an organic standpoint. And then the second part of your question was around contribution from a DAR, DCR. So from TCR and DCR, still early innings there. We've had a syndication has just taken place. As you know, we have had a number of clients working at the data for a while, so the revenue contribution is immaterial in the quarter and again I expect that to be much a greater contributor in 2017 going forward.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I'll also say though, as we've said in the past, Digital Ad Ratings, Digital Content Ratings, their presence in our portfolio completely changes the discussions, when we were renewing our contracts with the big media companies. And so while Jamere's c
componenttext: But I'll also say though, as we've said in the past, Digital Ad Ratings, Digital Content Ratings, their presence in our portfolio completely changes the discussions, when we were renewing our contracts with the big media companies. And so while Jamere's comment is more focused on the direct incremental revenues, which mostly come from digital first players in the marketplace, if you could imagine, which I don't really choose to do, but if you could imagine what our contract renewals would be like with the big media conglomerates if we didn't have digital ad ratings and digital content ratings and our Total Audience Measurement system, it would be a completely different picture than what you see rolling to our numbers in the quarter. That's by far the more significant contribution that those products make in our Watch business right now. And the other parts, we love as well. We love it just as much, but at the moment, not quite as big.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Dan Salmon from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Dan Salmon from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one question each on the Buy and Watch segments. Mitch, could you just refresh us on where your relationships with Amazon and Alibaba stand in terms of their participation in various Buy products? And then just on the Watch side, more of a minor one,
componenttext: Just one question each on the Buy and Watch segments. Mitch, could you just refresh us on where your relationships with Amazon and Alibaba stand in terms of their participation in various Buy products? And then just on the Watch side, more of a minor one, perhaps just an update on status in the audio market, both progress on your own initiatives as well as perhaps your comment on the competitive environment, as you know, the industry is looking for sort of a co-op collective solution or has initiated that, if you honestly have another independent competitor there, just interested to hear update on it as well.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. First, on your first question related to Buy and e-commerce. We continued the development of our e-commerce solution for the U.S., where we're bringing together some of our panel data, some other third-party data and big data sources all together in
componenttext: Sure. First, on your first question related to Buy and e-commerce. We continued the development of our e-commerce solution for the U.S., where we're bringing together some of our panel data, some other third-party data and big data sources all together in a hybrid solution that allows us to cover the rapidly growing e-commerce channels, both the extensions of the brick-and-mortar players and the pure-play e-commerce platforms, including the largest players out there. We're bringing that forward to the marketplace. And by the end of this year, that will be in the hands of a growing number of our clients and start to roll through our business in a more full way in 2017, that's the U.S and we have similar solutions that play basically the same, design depends on the country, in 11 other markets, where e-commerce sales are significant around the world. With regard to Amazon, they -- no change really in their status. In terms of their willingness to share their sales data, like retailers typically do with us, as we measure fast-moving consumer goods, they still prefer to remain on the outside of that collaboration model, cooperation model that advise our retail measurement service. So like we've done with Netflix on the Watch side of the business, we find other ways to measure the activity on those kinds of platforms. We've done that very successfully on the Watch side covering Netflix and other subscription video-on-demand platforms, and we are able to do it on the Buy said as well to measure what's happening on Amazon's platform. With regard to Alibaba, we continue to be very closely in touch and active with Alibaba in the China market as well as Tencent and Sina and [indiscernible] and a lot of the other really big players. In U.S., we have [indiscernible], Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google in China, they have their similar 4 or 5 major players and we're active with all of them. I was in China last month with our teams, and part of that also included a meeting with the most senior leaders at [indiscernible] and talking about how we're going to continue to broaden our relationship there. And Alibaba continues to be very active and a key focus for our business in the China market. On your -- on Part B of your 1 question, Dan, with regard to audio and the competitive situation in the industry, first, on audio, we are still thrilled with that business. It's exactly what we expected, low single-digit growth, strong free cash flows, you see us scheme leverage from audio business in a new way, leveraging the PPM measurement capability to add more effective sample size to our local TV measurement over on the video side of the equation. And then we are continuing to pursue international wins in the radio audience measurement business through the capabilities we have. We have some of those in our history, and there's a few more opportunities in front of us. And the other thing we're doing there is obviously continuing to bring our analytics portfolio to the radio industry to help them better tell their ROI and penetrations in the marketplace. On the cooperative industry collaboration that's going on, try to prop up a competitive alternative, uses ACR technology, automated content recognition technology, I think that's the one you're probably referring to. Look, we're very familiar with that kind of technology. We have it ourselves already in our tool bag. We know what it's good for and how -- what it's work well for and we also know quite a bit about limitations. And so we're staying focused on our strategy on audience measurement. And currency grade measurement that the marketplace trades on, it has representative panels that represent all the key segments of the marketplace in a manner that's always been important currently is and will remain important, that's what Nielsen is about, and that's easier said than done, we know that from experience.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ryan Cary from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ryan Cary from Jefferies.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: One more on the Buy business. Understand it's too early to give any 2017 guidance, how should we be thinking about the growth rates in the developed markets beyond 2016, even just directionally, clearly you're doing a lot to evolve the business so trying
componenttext: One more on the Buy business. Understand it's too early to give any 2017 guidance, how should we be thinking about the growth rates in the developed markets beyond 2016, even just directionally, clearly you're doing a lot to evolve the business so trying to gauge how long it'll take for the developed business to return to more historical growth rates?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start, maybe Jamere, you'll add. Especially for the U.S., we're planning for it to be a continued tough environment next year, so we're starting there. And then we're thinking about our cost base, our allocation resources, our investment in our key
componenttext: Let me start, maybe Jamere, you'll add. Especially for the U.S., we're planning for it to be a continued tough environment next year, so we're starting there. And then we're thinking about our cost base, our allocation resources, our investment in our key initiatives with that as a starting point. If the environment improves, then that's going to be great. But it doesn't, we are building our plan with that tough growth environment in mind. Again, because we don't see this as just a cycle that the market is passing through, that's our judgment of what we're seeing in the market place, we see it as more of a secular shift, and we're designing and transforming our product portfolio accordingly.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we'll give more color in December at Analyst Day, but I'll say from a total company standpoint, as you've all seen our long-term growth framework, what we guided for this year was in line with our long-term growth framework. And I would just say b
componenttext: I mean, we'll give more color in December at Analyst Day, but I'll say from a total company standpoint, as you've all seen our long-term growth framework, what we guided for this year was in line with our long-term growth framework. And I would just say based on what we're seeing in developed Buy, that we are planning for a year to [indiscernible] the lower end of that growth range. And again, we'll give a lot more color at Analyst Day. We're working through our 2017 operating plan over the next few weeks, and will throw out the picture there.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Nollen from Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Nollen from Macquarie.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it does seem like this is a fairly important initiative you're taking on, and there will be effects beyond the Q3 just reported. We have a Q4 guidance, I respect you're not going to give as much on 2017 yet, but your restructuring charges, as you menti
componenttext: So it does seem like this is a fairly important initiative you're taking on, and there will be effects beyond the Q3 just reported. We have a Q4 guidance, I respect you're not going to give as much on 2017 yet, but your restructuring charges, as you mentioned earlier, Jamere, are going to be towards the upper end. How will you be reporting restructuring and other below-the-line items after this year?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a great question. So as many of you know, when I took the CFO [indiscernible] in 2014, I related myself as a plain-vanilla kind of CFO and we're marching towards that path. I would say a couple of things. Those of you followed our business ove
componenttext: Yes, that's a great question. So as many of you know, when I took the CFO [indiscernible] in 2014, I related myself as a plain-vanilla kind of CFO and we're marching towards that path. I would say a couple of things. Those of you followed our business over the last few years know sort of where we've been consistently with things like restructuring and onetime items, cash, taxes, et cetera. So we've reached a point in our cycle, in our maturity that we know pretty much where those line items are going to come in and, quite frankly, we feel comfortable being measured against them. And so you'll see us provide more luck clarity around how we'll guide going forward at our 2017 Analyst Day.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tom Eagan with Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tom Eagan with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Just a follow-up on developed buy business. We saw the same light organic growth in the U.S. business versus other markets and several ad agencies this past quarter, namely, OMC and IPG. So is your business a leading indicator of theirs or vice ver
componenttext: Great. Just a follow-up on developed buy business. We saw the same light organic growth in the U.S. business versus other markets and several ad agencies this past quarter, namely, OMC and IPG. So is your business a leading indicator of theirs or vice versa? And then additionally, how would you describe or explain the dynamics for the -- for your competition in that business?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know that we are a lead versus theirs or vice versa. I think it's the same wallet in the a lot of the same dynamics. Within our portfolio, we do know that there are some parts that do tend to see these kinds of swings in the marketplace sooner tha
componenttext: I don't know that we are a lead versus theirs or vice versa. I think it's the same wallet in the a lot of the same dynamics. Within our portfolio, we do know that there are some parts that do tend to see these kinds of swings in the marketplace sooner than others. For instance, we've always seen that our innovation analytics, that innovation analytics part of our business, that tends to swing down or sing backup as a lead indicator of some of the other discretionary services in our portfolio. But, as a whole, I think our broad portfolio and a broad portfolio of services that the media and advertising agencies provide will probably moving more similarly to each other, rather than one being lead versus the other.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just think it's indicative of the environment. When we talk to our clients, particularly as I talk to CFOs of our clients, they're all very focused on every line item of the P&L, just like we are. And agencies aren't immune, the discretionary parts of o
componenttext: I just think it's indicative of the environment. When we talk to our clients, particularly as I talk to CFOs of our clients, they're all very focused on every line item of the P&L, just like we are. And agencies aren't immune, the discretionary parts of our business aren't immune, so I think it's just indicative of the environment you're seeing.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Meuler from Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Meuler from Baird.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the long-term framework, you've also provided us some margins. Can you talk a lot about margin levers, it sounds like you still think you have to pull. But just wanted to gauge your sense of comfort with the long-term margin framework you previously pr
componenttext: On the long-term framework, you've also provided us some margins. Can you talk a lot about margin levers, it sounds like you still think you have to pull. But just wanted to gauge your sense of comfort with the long-term margin framework you previously provided, and is it reasonable to expect that it may be below that, that pace of expansion at least in the intermediate term, call it 2017, 2018 as you go through some of these changes?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I said, we're currently working throughout 2017 operating plans over the next few weeks or so, and we'll certainly fill out the picture in December Analyst Day. Here are the things that I have a lot of confidence in. The first is that in our Buy b
componenttext: Yes, as I said, we're currently working throughout 2017 operating plans over the next few weeks or so, and we'll certainly fill out the picture in December Analyst Day. Here are the things that I have a lot of confidence in. The first is that in our Buy business, we continue to see scale benefits from the emerging markets and that's certainly a tailwind for margins. The intensity around cost out and productivity has not waned inside the company, and we got a very strong deck of productivity projects that are going to produce margin expansion for us inside the company. And I'd say the third thing is that the restructuring efforts that you saw us taken the last couple of quarters are going to give us the right trajectory. So again, we'll manage the margin expansion inside the total company. You'll see us guide to what that is and we'll balance that with the real window of opportunity that we have here to accelerate this during our Buy business and accelerate growth initiatives that we have in our Watch business.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Bill Warmington from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Bill Warmington from Wells Fargo.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to ask about the new rating standard and assuming it's ready in time for 2017 upfront, just to ask about the direct and indirect revenue opportunity for you guys, pricing module from so on. And then as part of that, I just wanted to double che
componenttext: So I wanted to ask about the new rating standard and assuming it's ready in time for 2017 upfront, just to ask about the direct and indirect revenue opportunity for you guys, pricing module from so on. And then as part of that, I just wanted to double check the Watch guidance that you've given for the segment. It had been 6% to 7% I believe and just wanted to double check that.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first one, Jamere will cover the second one. On the currency definition, I commented on that earlier, maybe just the thing to add, we've had a series of meetings with the industry most recent one was last week, we continue to narrow in on th
componenttext: I'll take the first one, Jamere will cover the second one. On the currency definition, I commented on that earlier, maybe just the thing to add, we've had a series of meetings with the industry most recent one was last week, we continue to narrow in on the definition, and there's a lot of reasons for us to be confident that our Total Audience Measurement system's going to play a big role in the 2017 upfront. Let me tell you what we're doing also, not just what Nielsen thinks, but what are some of the key industry players think. One example is Rino Scanzoni, he's the Chief Investment Officer at GroupM. He was quoted a few weeks ago saying something like, we're looking for to making the Total Audience the currency in the next upfront. And then what he said was we have to go there. There's 10% to 12% more audience if you factor in the viewing on these other devices. his voice is really important because, well, he was central to the C3 metric 10 years ago when that was converged on by the industry and has since served as the definition of the currency. So that's what -- how we know he's thinking about Total Audience new definition of the currency for the 2017 upfront. David [indiscernible], Chief Research officer at CBS, he was just more direct, he just said, "We're definitely moving forward." That was his attitude toward it. And so I think the keys to this way of thinking for these key industry influencers are the fact that we passed the syndication point for digital content ratings at the end of September. We are on the path to fully syndicate Total Content Ratings by the early part of 2017, already in full syndication for the participating publishers. We're just going to add agencies and other members of the ecosystem in the early part of the year. Those are the last key pieces of the puzzle. And so we've delivered on those, and that's why I think everybody's pretty confident in terms of this measurement system. And some sense of what that new currency definition is going to be, playing an important role in the 2017 upfront-s.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of our Watch guidance, I mean this year we guided 4.5% to 6.5%. You've seen this on a year to date basis be at above 6.3%. And for the fourth quarter, the only thing that, for those of you are modeling after adjust 4 is that remember, we lap the
componenttext: In terms of our Watch guidance, I mean this year we guided 4.5% to 6.5%. You've seen this on a year to date basis be at above 6.3%. And for the fourth quarter, the only thing that, for those of you are modeling after adjust 4 is that remember, we lap the EPS consolidation fourth quarter last year, and we are also lapping the NRG divestiture in the fourth quarter. So those are the material adjustments that you need to make the right ballpark.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ashwin Shirvaikar from Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ashwin Shirvaikar from Citi.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to go back to the Buy business. I think you as data tools and people. I'd say that the issues that you currently have are on the people based side of it. These are expensive resources that you have, former consultants and such. And as you do the re
componenttext: I want to go back to the Buy business. I think you as data tools and people. I'd say that the issues that you currently have are on the people based side of it. These are expensive resources that you have, former consultants and such. And as you do the restructuring, as you go through that, I just want to figure out what are we talking about in terms of eventual sort of headcount drops? What are we talking about in terms of cash restructuring associated with that? And then as you move to connected part and build out ecosystem, how's the economics going to work with regards to how you share across the system?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start, and I'll let Mitch sort of chime in. I think your characterization of our business is exactly right. What the connected system this is it traditions our business and more like an emphasis business than it does today. Currently, for a lot of th
componenttext: I'll start, and I'll let Mitch sort of chime in. I think your characterization of our business is exactly right. What the connected system this is it traditions our business and more like an emphasis business than it does today. Currently, for a lot of the things that we've been talking about, we are more of people a us a service business mix than a typical information service company, so the implication is that we'll have a higher-margin business close to transition, as we'll have more opportunities to sell data as a service and Software-as-a-Service business. And as Mitch said, tremendous value, reduce cost on the client side and it should help us be more efficient and more productive in terms of how we deliver that service to our clients. And so it's an exciting transition for us.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the idea of people remains every bit as important in that future business model versus how they've been important in our business historically. What it will mean is a different mix of people, slightly different set of skills and different roles inside
componenttext: And the idea of people remains every bit as important in that future business model versus how they've been important in our business historically. What it will mean is a different mix of people, slightly different set of skills and different roles inside the business. As our system, connected system, its usually important initiative that we're focused on is developed, it well be connected directly to our clients business process systems whereas right now,'s a lot of manual intervention required both on our side in on our client side in order to draw full value out of these data resources that we provide to our clients. So it creates a lot of efficiencies, both on our side and on our clients side. And that's a back to our point of about this is a stronger, higher-margin business, more valuable to Nielsen and more valuable to our clients. So it's a transition we'll work through. It's not a flip the switch kind of impact though. It's a gradual transition, it will evolve over time. We've done some restructuring already, and if we get to the point where we see the next move that needs to be made on that front, of course, you'll see us do it.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our final question today comes from Doug Arthur from Huber Research.
componenttext: Our final question today comes from Doug Arthur from Huber Research.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mitch, in terms of the national TV out-of-home measurement rollout, how significant could that be in terms of growth? Is it modest? Or were they modest?

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Modest. It'll be a very important addition to our capabilities for certain clients and not so important for others. For instance, if you are March madness, if you're one of the networks carrying much madness, this is a big deal. If you're CNN, if you're C
componenttext: Modest. It'll be a very important addition to our capabilities for certain clients and not so important for others. For instance, if you are March madness, if you're one of the networks carrying much madness, this is a big deal. If you're CNN, if you're CNBC, these kinds of networks, this is a big deal. But others, maybe their programming is more zero-based genre or sitcoms, things of that nature, this isn't a higher priority for those kinds of networks. And so you'll see it work its way through our clients portfolio accordingly, and it'll add up to being a modest impact on our business. But, that's what's required. When you take own the task of measuring Total Audience, you can't just go for the easy parts, for the more efficient parts, it's really live up to that, that standard and to fulfill that vision. You're going to take it all in, and this is part of that.

headline: Nielsen Holdings plc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to take 1 minute before we wrap up. Share a few closing thoughts in terms of how I see the overall picture. Watch business, again, we continue to be thrilled with the progress, the syndication of Digital Content Ratings and the path we're on for full
componenttext: Just to take 1 minute before we wrap up. Share a few closing thoughts in terms of how I see the overall picture. Watch business, again, we continue to be thrilled with the progress, the syndication of Digital Content Ratings and the path we're on for full syndication of Total Content Ratings, the overall Total Audience Measurement system gaining adoption and well positioned for the 2017 upfront. On top of that, the improvements that rolling out for our local TV ratings business, our Watch business really on a roll. Marketing Effectiveness, strong growth, more than 30% in the quarter. Our Buy business, emerging remains solid, even within developed, Europe, the Pacific, Canada all turned in solid quarters of growth. U.S. is where we have a decline, a tough environment we talked about, we are judging these to be secular shifts and we're responding accordingly in terms of the magnitude and the pace of the changes we're making in our business to reduce our cost base, reallocate our resources, accelerate our investments in particular in this connected system that helps us move from what today is much of a people as a service business model to being much more of a data as a service and Software-as-a-Service business model in the future, all that adds up to stronger, higher-margin business for Nielsen going forward, and we're going to continue to update you on our progress on the connected system front on future calls and, of course, at our December Analyst Day, much like we have done with Total Audience and its development over the past many quarters. So thanks again for everybody for tuning into the call, thanks for your questions, and we look forward to talking with you in the days and weeks ahead.
